According to them, such people are not worthy of being trusted, let alone being appointed by Allah as a Prophet.
text.9: In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet and his ummah to pay attention to the criticisms put forward by the disbelievers. By paying attention to these criticisms, it becomes clear that they have run out of reasons and explanations to reject the Prophet Muhammad's call to tawhid and to abandon their misleading objects of worship. They are unable to refute the reasons and proofs presented by the Prophet Muhammad in the form of verses of the Al-Qur'an and others. They are unable to answer the challenge to produce even one surah that is equal in value to one surah in the Al-Qur'an, whether in terms of content, meaning, or literature. Therefore, they shift their criticisms to the person of the Prophet Muhammad himself. This often happens to people whose arguments have been defeated. Therefore, Allah does not directly answer these criticisms but commands that they be displayed so that it is clear to everyone that they have been thrown into a corner because they have indeed strayed from the right path.
text.10:
As a consolation to the Prophet who was constantly insulted and belittled by the disbelievers, Allah explains that if He willed, He would have given him gardens better than those requested by the disbelievers and would have given him the most magnificent and beautiful palaces. This would be very easy for Allah, but that is not what He willed. Allah willed that the Messenger who carries His message be an ordinary human being who is a role model and example for his people in striving for an ideal, fighting for the truth, and exalting the word of Allah.

In addition to the very difficult struggle, the Prophet also had to think about his personal needs and desires. That is how a Messenger who will be an example and role model should be. If the Prophet Muhammad were a rich man with gardens, palaces, and abundant treasures, his struggle would not be as great, and it would not be possible for his followers to emulate him later. What is the meaning of a palace, what is the meaning of gardens, and what is the meaning of abundant treasures when one is faced with his Creator, the Almighty, the All-Rich, and the All-Powerful? Thus, the Prophet Muhammad was content with his condition. Even though he was poor, weak, and received various insults and mockery from his people, he was happy and content because he carried a sacred duty from his Lord. He once said, "O my Lord, whatever happens to me and however heavy my suffering, I am still happy as long as You are pleased with me."
text.11: In this verse, Allah reaffirms that the disbelievers have strayed far from the right path, and they even deny the coming of the Day of Judgment, the Day of Recompense where all of humanity's deeds will be justly rewarded. Good deeds will be rewarded with manifold blessings, and evil deeds will be punished with a painful torment. They deny the Day of Judgment so that they can act arbitrarily towards the weak, and reign supreme in committing injustice. Therefore, Allah threatens them with a blazing fire of Hell as a consequence of their denial and disobedience, and as a consequence of their evil deeds in the world.
text.12: When the disbelievers are driven to Hell, it is as if Hell sees them from afar, and its roaring sound is heard due to its anger at seeing the disbelievers, as if Hell is a hungry lion seeing its prey approaching. Ibn Munzir and Ibn Jarir narrate that Ubaid bin Umair said, "Indeed, Jahannam roars with a sound that causes the angels and prophets to tremble in their joints upon hearing it, so that Prophet Ibrahim falls to his knees and says, "O my Lord, I ask for nothing today except my own safety." One can imagine how terrifying the situation will be at that time, how terrible the punishment they will receive, and how heavy the suffering they will feel at that time.
text.13: When they are thrown into a narrow place in Hell, with their hands bound [to their necks], there they will cry out, "Woe to us! Why did we previously disregard the guidance revealed by Allah through His Messenger? Why did we dispute and reject it? Truly, we are the wretched ones!"
text.14: At that time, it was said to them not to utter that word (woe is me) only once. Utter that word repeatedly because what they see and experience is only one type of punishment that will be inflicted upon them. There are many more types of punishments they will suffer. Therefore, scream repeatedly, indeed they will be afflicted with a terrible and severe punishment.
text.15: Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to say to the disbelievers, is such a terrible and dreadful punishment better than the Paradise full of blessings and mercy that has been prepared for the believers who are pious? They will abide therein forever. That Paradise is made for them because they believe in Allah and His Messenger, and are obedient and compliant in carrying out His commands and avoiding all His prohibitions.
text.16:
In Paradise, they will be given whatever they ask for and desire, in the form of clothing, food, drink, and all the pleasures that cannot be imagined by humans in this world. In addition to that, they will always be in Divine pleasure, and this is a spiritual blessing without equal, because Divine pleasure is what brings peace and happiness to the depths of the heart of every servant of Allah, as mentioned in His word.

Allah says, "This is the Day when the truthful will benefit from their truthfulness. For them are gardens [in Paradise] beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever, Allah being pleased with them and they with Him. That is the great attainment." (al-Ma'idah/5: 119)

Such is the promise of Allah to His believing and pious servants, and the promise of Allah is certain to be fulfilled.
text.17:
On the Day of Judgment, the polytheists will be gathered together with their objects of worship. Then Allah will pose questions to those objects of worship. Is it true that they used to command them in the world to worship them, causing them to stray from the right path, associating partners with Allah through those objects of worship, thus denying the teachings of Allah and the teachings of His Messenger? Among the objects of worship that the disbelievers worshipped were some angels, Prophet Isa (Jesus), and Uzair (Ezra). They will be very surprised and astonished to hear these questions because they never commanded people to worship them; in fact, they always called to *tauhid* (monotheism), worshipping Allah without associating anything with Him. In this verse, Allah's question specifically directed to Prophet Isa is mentioned, which is His saying:

"And [beware the Day] when Allah will say, "O Jesus, Son of Mary, did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?'" He will say, "Exalted are You! It was not for me to say that to which I had no right. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within myself, and I do not know what is within Yourself. Indeed, it is You who is the Knower of the unseen." (al-Ma'idah/5: 116)
text.18: Spontaneously, they answered Allah's question, which they had not expected to be posed to them at all. They replied in unison, "Glory be to You, O our Lord, it is not fitting for us to take protectors besides You. This is our belief because there is none worthy of worship and to be taken as a protector except You alone. How could we command others to worship other than You when that contradicts our creed and faith? Perhaps You, O our Lord, have bestowed upon them Your blessings and mercy so that they would be grateful to You, but they used those blessings and mercy for the satisfaction of their desires, so that they became immersed in pleasure and delight. Finally, they forgot You and fell into the abyss of error and could no longer be helped and are included among those who are destroyed."
text.19: Allah directs His word to those polytheists. You have heard for yourselves the answer of those you worship. It is now clear that they did not mislead you; they never commanded you to worship them. So, you yourselves fabricated gods besides Me. Now you will never be able to escape My punishment, and no one will be able to give you help. You have wronged yourselves by fabricating gods besides Me, and the fate of those who wrong themselves by worshipping other than Me, I will surely cast into a painful and severe punishment.
text.20:
In this verse, Allah explains to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) that the previous messengers also ate and drank like him. The criticisms of the disbelievers towards him were very painful to Muhammad (peace be upon him). These criticisms were not merely criticisms, but also contained insults that greatly demeaned him, even though he was a Messenger honored by Allah. So, to comfort and alleviate the inner pressure suffered by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) due to these criticisms and insults, Allah stated to him that He had never sent a messenger before like the one desired by the disbelievers of Mecca.

All the Messengers He sent were human beings who were not free from human traits, but needed food and drink, and continued to strive to fulfill their needs in accordance with His word in other verses:

"And We sent not before you (O Muhammad) except men to whom We revealed [Our message]. So ask the people of the message if you do not know. And We did not make them bodies not eating food, nor were they immortal." (al-Anbiya'/21: 7-8)

So, the difference between a human being as a Messenger and a human being in general lies in his personal virtues, the loftiness of his morals, the purity of his heart, and his sincerity in carrying out his duties. Therefore, Allah's revelation was sent down to him and strengthened with miracles that no human being could match, let alone defeat. So, the mockery and criticism of the disbelievers were far from the mark, and should not have been directed at Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). If they truly wanted to invalidate the truth he brought, they should not have presented such criticisms.

They had been challenged to match the miracle given to him by Allah, which was to create just one short surah of similar value to a short surah from the Al-Qur'an. But they were powerless and unable to do so, even though they were among the intelligent and highly literate people. Only hatred and envy had darkened their hearts, and fear of losing influence and position had unleashed their anger. Therefore, they continued to challenge, even though in their hearts they had realized their error.

Then Allah also explains that humans are tested with various kinds of trials. Each human being is given the freedom to either be steadfast and patient in facing the trial, or to turn away from the truth because they cannot bear the anger and envy in their hearts. Allah made some humans as Prophets and Messengers, bearers of His message, others He made kings and rulers who have power over other humans, others He made rich and strong, poor and weak, and so on. People who use their minds and thoughts, especially those who believe, will not be influenced by differences in levels, degrees, wealth, and position, but will continue to accept what is right and reject what is wrong, regardless of where the truth comes from, whether the truth comes from a head of state or a minister, or from a lowly person with no influence whatsoever.

Ali bin Abi Talib once said, "Pay attention to what is said and do not pay attention to who is saying it." The poor are tested in the steadfastness of their hearts in facing their state of deprivation, unlike the rich who can enjoy various kinds of physical pleasures with their wealth.

The disbelievers of Mecca were tested in the purity of their hearts by giving the gift of prophethood to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), while he was just an ordinary person among them, not from the rich or from influential tribal leaders. All humans are tested in their mental strength in facing the differences and divisions between various groups in society. Whoever wins in facing that test is the one who will attain happiness in life, both in this world and in the hereafter. In a hadith narrated by Imam Muslim, Rasulullah (peace be upon him) said:

"Look at those who are lower than you in status, and do not look at those who are higher than you, because looking at those who are higher will lead you to belittling the value of the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon you." (Riwayat Muslim)

Such are the trials that Allah gives to His servants, and He knows best who among His servants is steadfast and patient in facing the trial, so that he is included among those who pass and win. He will give the best reward to the winners and will inflict punishment on the losers who, because of their impatience and arrogance, even disobey the blessings that He has given them.
text.21:
Those who do not believe in the Day of Resurrection or deny the Day of Judgment, when they will be brought before Allah to be judged for all their deeds in the world, arrogantly ask why angels were not sent down to them to be witnesses to the truth of Muhammad as a prophet, to eliminate their doubts about the truth of the revelation sent down to him. If that is difficult to implement, why don't they directly see God who will explain to them that Muhammad was truly sent by Him to deliver good news and give warnings. If that were to happen, they say they would believe in Muhammad. Such statements are nothing but their own arrogance, and because of their injustice in denying a messenger of Allah.

They completely ignore the clear miracles that the Messenger of Allah has shown them. Every sane person would be astonished to hear their words and consider them the words of an irrational person. Even if Allah granted that wish, they still would not believe in Allah and His Messenger, as stated in Allah's word:

And even if We had sent down angels to them, and the dead had spoken to them, and We had gathered before them all things (they desired), they would still not believe, unless Allah willed. But most of them do not know (the meaning of truth). (al-An'am/6: 111)

21. This verse explains another excuse made up by the polytheists of Mecca because of their reluctance to believe in the Prophet Muhammad. And those who do not expect to meet Us in the Hereafter because of their denial of the existence of the Hereafter, or because of their lack of fear of it, they say, "Why are not the angels sent down to us in their real form, who tell us about the truth of the Prophet Muhammad, or why do we not see our Lord? with our own eyes who also tell us about the truth of the Prophet Muhammad." These requests are clearly fabricated, the same as what the Children of Israel did in the past. This clearly arises from their hearts full of envy. Indeed, they have become arrogant because they are seduced by their desires. They consider themselves more noble, either because of their wealth or their position in society. And they have truly exceeded the limits in committing injustice. Thus, if the heart is closed off by disbelief, all the truth that is in front of it, even if it is already crystal clear, is completely ignored.
text.22:
This verse explains the condition of the disbelievers and polytheists when they meet the angels in the afterlife. The angels they desired as messengers in the world, or as witnesses to the truth of Muhammad's prophethood, they will meet in the afterlife. However, this meeting will not be as they expected because they will not hear good news from those angels, whether in the form of forgiveness of sins, or an order to enter Paradise. They will only hear a very painful saying, namely *hijran mahjuran*, which means "(Paradise) is forbidden and prohibited to them." The angel's utterance is considered very painful, because it is usually said by Arabs when they encounter difficulties.

As for the believers, they are welcomed by the angels who come to meet them and give them good news to enter Paradise. This is described in Allah's word:

"Indeed, those who have said, "Our Lord is Allah" and then remained steadfast - the angels will descend upon them, [saying], "Do not fear and do not grieve, but receive good tidings of Paradise, which you were promised." (Fussilat/41: 30)
text.23: In this verse, Allah explains the causes of misfortune and loss for disbelievers. Allah will show all the deeds they considered good that they performed during their lives in the world, such as maintaining kinship ties (silaturrahim), helping those who are suffering, giving donations to alleviate natural disasters, providing assistance to hospitals and orphans, freeing or ransoming prisoners, and so on. No matter how much good they do, they will not receive any reward from Allah. They can only look at those good deeds without being able to benefit from them in the slightest. Those good deeds are then made by Allah like dust scattered in the air because they are not based on true faith in Allah. They can only sit in contemplation, filled with regret. That is what they feel as a result of their disbelief (kufr) and arrogance.
text.24:
In contrast to the fate of the people mentioned above, those who believe will be inhabitants of Paradise in the Hereafter. They will obtain a dwelling place that is far better than the residences of the polytheists in the world, which they always made symbols of grandeur and luxury. The dwelling place of the people of Paradise is the most comfortable resting place. The pleasures of the world are only temporary because they can only be felt during life in the world, and their pleasures can be deceptive, as stated in the word of Allah:

"Every soul will taste death. And you will only be given your [full] compensation on the Day of Resurrection. So he who is drawn away from the Fire and admitted to Paradise has attained [his desire]. And what is the life of this world except the enjoyment of delusion." (ali 'Imran/3: 185).
text.25:
In this verse, Allah commands Muhammad to explain to his people the terrors of the Day of Judgment. At that time, the sky will split open, and all celestial bodies within it will be destroyed like scattered mist, due to the collision of planets and stars that no longer orbit according to their respective regulations, as explained in Allah's words:

And the heaven is opened and becomes as gates. And the mountains are removed and will be [as] a mirage. (an-Naba'/78: 19-20)

When the sky is cleft asunder; And when the stars fall, scattering; And when the seas are erupted; And when the graves are overturned - A soul will [then] know what it has put forth and kept back. (al-Infithar/82: 1-5)

On that terrible day, angels will descend in waves, carrying books containing records of all the deeds of Allah's servants that they witnessed and recorded while on Earth. These books will become evidence when they are judged by Allah in the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar).

According to scientists, this verse, like many other verses in the Qur'an, affirms the occurrence of extraordinary astronomical events of immense terror that will occur on the Day of Judgment. All of this indicates complete damage and destruction in the system that connects the parts of the universe. This includes a total change in the position, shape, and connections between elements in this vast universe. A final picture and total change that does not only occur on Earth, but also encompasses all the celestial bodies in this universe. Stars "fall," collide with each other, due to the destruction (loss) of gravity, the sky splits apart, and planets collide and scatter.

The white mist describes all the celestial bodies, trillions in number, as if seen as mist. At that time, these celestial bodies "shoot" out of the sky as if pushed from within by great pressure that forces them out of the "balloon" of the sky. Stars, planets, and other celestial bodies are no different from small and light dust "that has no power whatsoever." The balance and order between the components of the system in the universe at that time no longer exist. Celestial bodies collide and explode. It could be that the white mist is also clouds gathered from the vapors produced by these explosions.
text.26:
This verse explains that the true and genuine kingdom on the Day of Judgment belongs to Allah, while the kingdoms that once existed in the world are not eternal.

"Whose is the kingdom this Day?" [It belongs] to Allah, the One, the Prevailing. (al-Mu'min/40: 16)

As the owner of the true kingdom, Allah is the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, and the Most Just when judging His servants, especially those who believe and obediently carry out His commands. Conversely, for the disbelievers, the Hereafter is a very difficult day, because the gods they worship cannot give intercession or help. The various difficulties they face make them despair. The situation faced by the disbelievers is described in the Qur'an:

And if every wrongdoer possessed all that is on earth and sought to ransom himself with it, it would not be accepted of him. And they will conceal their regret when they see the punishment. And they will be judged in justice, and they will not be wronged. (Yunus/10: 54)
text.27:
On that Day, the wrongdoers will bite their fingers in regret for neglecting their obligations during their life in the world. Arrogantly, they turned away from the truth brought to them by the messengers of Allah. They will weep bitterly, regretting that if only they had followed the invitation of the Messenger of Allah to the straight path that leads to salvation in this world and the hereafter. They will say with deep regret, "If only I had followed Muhammad in the world, together with him towards the right path. If only I could have restrained my arrogance so that I could sincerely embrace Islam, surely I would not be experiencing this difficulty." Alas, that regret will be of no use.

They will regret choosing the wrong friends. This is a great misfortune and destruction. "If only I had not made so-and-so my close friend, surely he would not have led me astray." Indeed, what leads people to misfortune and astray is sometimes Satan himself or Satan in the form of humans, such as an Arab polytheist named Ubay bin Khalaf.

The friendship of 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith with Ubay bin Khalaf had a great influence on him. 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith often attended the Prophet Muhammad's recitations, becoming a good acquaintance. One day, he invited the Prophet Muhammad to eat at his house. At that time, the Prophet refused to eat unless 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith embraced Islam, so 'Uqbah recited the two statements of faith (syahadat).

However, 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith's friend, Ubay bin Khalaf, was displeased and angry with him. 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith then said that he had only pretended to embrace Islam. Ubay bin Khalaf ordered 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith to spit on the face of the Prophet Muhammad. He then did so while the Prophet was performing prayer in Dar an-Nadwah, near the Baitullah. 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith obeyed what his friend wanted. Such is the consequence of friendship with bad people, which will bring bad consequences as well.

The Prophet Muhammad gave guidance to always seek good friends or close companions. His saying:

"A person will follow the behavior of his friend, so pay attention to who your friend is." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and at-Tirmidzi from Abu Hurairah)

And the saying of Rasulullah saw:

"The parable of a good and a bad companion is like a carrier of musk and a blacksmith. The carrier of musk may give you some musk, or you may buy some from him. At the very least, you will smell its fragrance. As for the blacksmith, he may burn your clothes (with sparks from his fire), or you will encounter a foul odor." (Narrated by asy-Syaikhan from Abu Musa al-Asy'ari).
text.28:
On that Day, the wrongdoers will bite their fingers in regret for having neglected their obligations during their lives in the world. Arrogantly, they turned away from the truth brought to them by the messengers of Allah. They weep bitterly, regretting that if only they had followed the invitation of the Messenger of Allah to the straight path that leads to salvation in this world and the hereafter when they were alive. They say with deep regret, "If only I had followed Muhammad in the world, together with him towards the right path. If only I could have restrained my arrogance so that I could sincerely embrace Islam, surely I would not be experiencing this difficulty." Alas, that regret is of no use anymore.

They regret choosing the wrong friends. This is a great misfortune and destruction. "If only I had not made so-and-so my close friend, surely he would not have led me astray." Indeed, what leads people into misfortune and error is sometimes Satan himself or Satan in the form of humans, such as an Arab polytheist named Ubay bin Khalaf.

The friendship of 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith with Ubay bin Khalaf was very influential for him. 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith often attended the Prophet Muhammad's recitations, becoming a good acquaintance. One day, he invited the Prophet Muhammad to eat at his house. At that time, the Prophet did not want to eat unless 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith converted to Islam, so 'Uqbah recited the two sentences of the *shahada*.

However, 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith's friend, Ubay bin Khalaf, was not pleased and was angry with him. 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith then said that he had only pretended to convert to Islam. Ubay bin Khalaf ordered 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith to spit in the face of the Prophet Muhammad. He then did so while the Prophet was performing *salat* in Dar an-Nadwah, near Baitullah. 'Uqbah bin Abi Mu'aith obeyed what his friend wanted. Such is the consequence of friendship with bad people, which will bring bad consequences as well.

The Prophet Muhammad gave guidance to always seek good friends or close companions. He said:

A person will follow the behavior of his friend, so pay attention to who your friend is. (Narrated by Abu Dawud and at-Tirmidhi from Abu Hurairah)

And the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

The parable of a good and a bad companion is like the bearer of musk and the blacksmith. The bearer of musk may give you some, or you may buy some from him. And at the very least, you will get a pleasant scent from him. As for the blacksmith, he may burn your clothes (because of the sparks from his fire) or you will encounter an unpleasant smell." (Narrated by asy-Syaikhan from Abu Musa al-Asy'ari).
text.29: This verse explains that the disbelievers say, "Someone has misled me from the teachings of the Qur'an and from believing in Muhammad after guidance had come to me." It is the habit of Satan to deceive people and turn them away from the truth, and he will not help the people he has misled.
text.30: In this verse, the Messenger of Allah complains to Allah, saying, "O my Lord, indeed my people have treated this Qur'an as [something] abandoned." They do not believe in it, nor do they pay attention to its promises and warnings. They even turn away from it and refuse to follow it. Then Allah commands His Messenger to be patient and steadfast in facing his people.
text.31:
Allah has made for every prophet an enemy from the devils and evil people who always mock the sanctity of religion and belittle the guidance brought by the messengers to them. Therefore, Allah advises the Prophet not to despair or feel alone in facing such challenges, because Allah is sufficient as the giver of guidance and helper. In accordance with Allah's word:

And thus We have appointed for every prophet an enemy - devils from mankind and jinn, inspiring to one another decorative speech as delusion. (al-An'am/6: 112)
text.32:
The disbelievers and the Jews asked why the Qur'an was not revealed to Muhammad all at once, like the previous books of Allah, namely the Torah to Moses and the Psalms to David. Allah rejected their question and explained why the Qur'an was revealed gradually. The Qur'an was revealed gradually so that Allah could make it easier and strengthen the heart of the Prophet Muhammad. Allah says:

And the Qur'an (We revealed) gradually so that you (Muhammad) may recite it to people at intervals. And We have revealed it in stages. (al-Isra'/17: 106)

The gradual revelation of the Qur'an indeed contains many wisdoms, including:

1. The Prophet Muhammad often met with the angel Gabriel, thus receiving much advice to increase his enthusiasm, patience, and perseverance in carrying out His message.

2. Because the Prophet Muhammad could not read and write (ummi), if the Qur'an had been revealed all at once, he would certainly have had difficulty memorizing it.

3. So that his memorization would be more solid, perfect, and free from all forgetfulness.

4. If the Qur'an had been revealed all at once, then its laws would also have been revealed all at once. This would certainly have caused many difficulties. However, because it was revealed gradually, the sharia was also implemented gradually, making it easy to implement, both by the Messenger and his people.

5. Because the revelation of the Qur'an is often related to the reasons for its revelation, such as various questions, events, or incidents, its gradual revelation is more memorable in the hearts of the companions because they can appreciate it event by event.

6. If they are unable to imitate the Qur'an even with the gradual revelation of the Qur'an, even a single verse, what more if it were revealed all at once.

7. Some of the laws of Islamic sharia were revealed according to the development of the Muslims at that time. Then, after they became more intelligent and firm in their faith, the more perfect Islamic sharia was applied with the verses of the Qur'an that were revealed later. If the Qur'an had been revealed all at once, this would not have been possible.
text.33:
In this verse, Allah tells Prophet Muhammad that He will not allow the disbelievers to come to the Prophet with something false that they fabricate to tarnish his prophethood. Allah will only bring to the Prophet something true to refute their accusations and provide the best explanation. This is also mentioned in Allah's word:

Nay, We hurl the truth against falsehood, and it knocks out its brain, and behold, falsehood vanishes! (al-Anbiya'/21: 18)
text.34:
This verse explains that those who are driven to Hell, by dragging their faces with chains and shackles, are the worst in terms of their place and the most misguided in their path. The Prophet Muhammad was commanded by Allah to say these words to the disbelievers who put forward some strange attributes to tarnish his prophethood, with the intention as if he was asking them to make a comparison of who among them was guided and who was in error. This is in accordance with Allah's word:

"And indeed, we or you are either upon guidance or in clear error." (Saba'/34: 24)

It is also mentioned in a hadith of the Messenger of Allah (saw):

"People will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection in three groups: one group walking on foot, another group riding, and another group walking on their faces." The Messenger of Allah was asked, "How can they walk on their faces?" He replied, "Indeed, the Lord who can make them walk on their feet is also able to make them walk on their faces. Remember, they will protect their faces from sharp and thorny objects." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Abu Hurairah).

What is meant here is that the angels drag the faces of the disbelievers into Hell.
text.35: This verse explains that Allah revealed the Torah to Prophet Musa (Moses) just as He revealed the Qur'an to Prophet Muhammad. He also made Harun (Aaron), his brother, accompany him as a *wazir* (helper) who was always consulted for his opinion. In another verse, it is explained that Harun was given as an assistant to Musa as a prophet. This is not contradictory because even though Harun was a prophet, in the field of *sharia* he followed the *sharia* of Musa and followed his guidance. Then Allah explains that Musa and Harun were commanded to convey His message to Pharaoh with the guarantee that the ultimate victory would certainly be on their side.
text.36:
Then Allah commanded Moses and Aaron to go and preach to Pharaoh and his people who had denied the signs of Allah's Oneness found in the universe. After they fulfilled their duty of conveying His message with gentleness, it turned out that Pharaoh's attitude remained unchanged, so Allah destroyed them. As stated in Allah's word:

"Allah has destroyed them, and for the disbelievers will be the like thereof." (Muhammad/47: 10).

With this event, Allah comforted the Prophet Muhammad and educated him to be patient, because he was not the first prophet to be denied by his people.
text.37:
Similarly, Allah destroyed the people of Noah who had denied the messengers. After Prophet Noah fulfilled his mission by conveying the da'wah to his people, but only a very few believed in him, Allah then drowned them with a great flood and deluge that destroyed all humans and animals except those on Noah's ark. Allah made that event a lesson for mankind so that they would always remember and be grateful for Allah's blessings that had saved them from threatening disasters. This is in accordance with Allah's word:

"Indeed, when the water overflowed, We carried you in the ship, That We might make it a reminder for you and that conscious ears might be conscious of it." (al-Haqqah/69: 11-12).

Then Allah explains the consequences for those who deny the message of the Prophet with His saying that He has prepared a painful punishment for the wrongdoers. This verse contains a warning to the Quraysh so that they do not deny the prophethood of Muhammad because it is highly likely that they too will be afflicted with punishment like the previous peoples who denied His messengers.
text.38: This verse explains that Allah destroyed the 'Ad people, the people of Prophet Hud, with a wind that blew with immense power and extreme cold, destroyed the Thamud people, the people of Prophet Saleh, with a loud, thunderous sound, and also destroyed the inhabitants of Rass in the land of Yamamah who had killed a prophet. The same fate also befell subsequent generations due to their disobedience.
text.39: In this verse, Allah explains that the Prophet should narrate the stories of past peoples to the polytheists as parables or lessons, and to explain to them the proofs of Allah's Oneness. However, it turned out that they continuously denied and rejected it, so Allah destroyed them utterly. Allah then commanded Muhammad to remind the polytheists of Mecca to take lessons from these various events. They always passed through the places of the destroyed peoples during their trading journeys, namely the remains of the regions of the people of Lut and Thamud when they went to Syria, and the remains of the region of the people of 'Ad (Ahqaf) which they passed when going to Yemen.
text.40: Indeed, the polytheists of Mecca often passed through the land of Sodom, which had once been rained upon with stones, and the former dwellings of the people of Prophet Lot, who were known for their homosexual acts. Did they not witness the remnants of those ruins as a punishment for denying a messenger of Allah? Then Allah explains that the main reason that closed their hearts to the causes of the descent of punishment was not because they did not see, but because they did not believe in the Day of Resurrection on the Day of Judgment, after they died.
text.41: In this verse, Allah affirms to the Prophet Muhammad that the disbelievers always mock him by saying, "Is this the one who has been sent as a messenger?" That is the mockery of the disbelievers every time they see the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him.
text.42:
The statement of the polytheists that Muhammad almost led them astray from their deities, had they not been diligent and patient in worshipping them, shows that the Prophet Muhammad had conveyed his message earnestly, accompanied by clear arguments. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) also displayed various miracles, so that they almost abandoned the religion of their ancestors and entered Islam. Their statement also indicates a great conflict in their hearts; on the one hand, they mocked the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and on the other hand, they were worried about being influenced by the Prophet's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) very strong and logical message.

Furthermore, this verse explains that they will know who is astray when they see the punishment. According to a narration, this verse is related to the actions of Abu Jahl every time he met the Messenger of Allah. Similar actions were done by previous peoples to the Messengers of Allah, as mentioned in Allah's word:

And already messengers were ridiculed before you, but those who mocked them were enveloped by that which they used to ridicule. (al-An'am/6: 10)
text.43:
Ibn 'Abbas r.a. said, "People in the Jahiliyyah era used to worship white stones for a period of time. However, if they saw another object of worship that was better, they would abandon the white stone and choose the second object of worship that was better according to the measure of their desires. In connection with that, this verse was revealed."

In this verse, Allah criticizes the disbelievers of Mecca who deified their desires, making them the basis for all their religious affairs. They did not listen to clear arguments and obvious explanations. Allah advises Muhammad not to worry too much about their attitude, because he was not assigned to make them believe forever, especially if they did not want to free themselves from the shackles of their desires and follow the guidance to the truth. Allah says that Muhammad is not their guardian or guarantor. The obligation of the Prophet saw is only to convey the message. This is in accordance with Allah's saying:

"You are not a dictator over them." (al-Ghashiyah/88: 22)
text.44:
In this verse, Allah advises the Prophet Muhammad not to assume that most of the polytheists listen to the verses and understand the truth contained within them, so that they can practice its guidance to perform good deeds and improve their morals. Allah reminds him of this because they are like livestock, even more astray. Compared to livestock, animals are submissive to their masters, feel loved by them, know who does good and who does evil to them, can find their own places where there is grass for food and water for drink, and know to return to their pens at night, which is very different from the polytheists themselves. They do not want to recognize the Creator and Provider of sustenance, they do not feel the various blessings bestowed upon them by God.

The polytheists do not feel deceived by Satan, who always views the enticements of their desires as good. The ignorance of livestock is limited only to themselves, but their ignorance spreads to cause various slanders and destruction, and to hinder others from the path of truth, even causing division and wars among fellow human beings. Although animals do not know about monotheism (tauhid) and prophethood, they do not oppose it, unlike the polytheists who deny monotheism because of arrogance and fanaticism towards the erroneous teachings inherited from their ancestors. Livestock does not waste the instinct that Allah has bestowed upon them. It is different with the polytheists; they are endowed with reason and good instincts from birth, but they waste that sound mind to distinguish between what is good and what is not.

The verse mentions that most of them do not hear or understand the truth. Indeed, there are a small number among them who acknowledge the truth, but are unable to follow it because they fear losing their position.
text.45: In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to observe His creation, how He lengthens and shortens the shadows of every object exposed to sunlight, from sunrise to sunset. Allah deliberately creates heat from the intense sunlight. If He willed, He could have made the shadows constant, unmoving. Allah makes the shadows lengthen or shorten for humans to use as a measure of time, as in Egypt they use a device called *al-Misallat* to measure time during the day and determine the seasons throughout the year. Since ancient times, the Arabs have also used a device called *al-Mazawil* to determine the times of prayer using shadows. They could ascertain the arrival of the time for Zuhr prayer when the shadow of the needle had moved from west to east, and the arrival of the time for Asr prayer when the shadow of every standing object had become equal to it. Only Imam Abu Hanifah holds the opinion that the shadow must be twice the length of the object itself. Thus, it is clear that according to this verse, Allah makes the shadows from sunlight as an indicator of time.
text.46:
Then Allah gradually erased those shadows in line with the process of the sun setting little by little. According to scientists, this verse speaks of the precision of the order of the universe. This verse explains the function of movement and the "length" of shadows that move from morning, noon, and afternoon. Lengthening the shadow of an object in physics is the event of the angle of incidence of light decreasing and the length of the shadow shortening due to the increasing angle of incidence of light. We often encounter this event in our daily lives. In the morning, the shadows of objects due to sunlight falling on the earth will appear long. As the day progresses and the sun reaches its culmination point, the shadow will appear shorter and shorter. Conversely, when the sun begins to shift westward until late afternoon, the shadows will be seen to lengthen again. This happens because the angle of incidence of sunlight becomes smaller again.

What happens when the length of the shadows remains constant or does not change? This is an extraordinary event. In simple terms, it can be interpreted that the position of the sun and the earth remain unchanged, so the sun will continuously illuminate the earth. This means that the surface of the earth (which is bright) will experience a heating process. The surface temperature will continue to increase as long as the sun shines. Seawater will bubble and boil. If this continues for a long time, the earth will burn and be destroyed due to the increasing temperature. Meanwhile, the surface of the earth that does not face the sun will experience the opposite process, namely extraordinary cooling. The sea surface may freeze, and life will die. These extreme temperature conditions in both hemispheres may lead to the extinction of life. Is it the Day of Judgment? *Wallahu a'lam.* Allah is All-Powerful over all His creations.

The event of the shadows being long and short or the west and east direction of the shadows in relation to the position of the sun can be a time indicator for humans on earth. The disappearance of shadows that occurs gradually is a simple illustration of the event of the sun setting gradually.

The second thing that can be obtained is that the verse above already indicates the earth's rotation on its axis. The verse below can also be used for this indication.

And the sun runs [on course] toward its stopping point. That is the determination of (Allah), the Exalted in Might, the Knowing. And the moon - We have determined for it phases, until it returns [again] as the old palm stalk. It is not allowable for the sun to reach the moon, nor does the night overtake the day, but each, in an orbit, is swimming. (Yasin/36: 38-40).

The verse above can also be used to show the order in the universe. The last sentence of the verse clearly states it. Similar things can also be found in Surah al-Anbiya'/21: 33, az-Zumar/39: 5, and ar-Rahman/55: 1-5.

In Surah Yasin/36: 38-40 above, it is mentioned that the sun runs on its course. Modern astronomy proves the truth of this statement in the Qur'an. As is known, the sun is located on the outer edge of the disk of the Milky Way galaxy. This galaxy is disk-shaped, which has a radius of about 10 kiloparsecs. If calculated in miles, it is equal to 2 with 17 zeros. Astronomical research shows that the Milky Way galaxy rotates on its axis (revolution), and one revolution takes 250 million years. Because the sun is located on the outer disk of this galaxy, the sun also revolves according to the orbital path of the outer edge of the galaxy disk.

The word *yasbahun* contained in Surah Yasin/36: 40, is more appropriately translated as swimming, than revolving. Because, in modern astronomy, space is not completely empty, but contains and is filled with sub-atomic particles known as neutrinos. So all celestial bodies in the universe are actually 'swimming' in neutrino waves.

Regarding the earth's rotation, data shows that the earth rotates on its axis at a speed of 1,670 km per hour. This speed is close to the speed of a bullet fired from a modern weapon, which is 1,800 km per hour. So it can be imagined how fast the earth's rotation is. What rotates this fast is not a small and light object like a bullet, but an object with a very large size and mass. The speed of the earth's orbit around the sun is about 60 times the speed of a bullet, which is about 108,000 km per hour. At that speed, an airplane would be able to circle the earth in 22 minutes.

The precision of the rotation that results in day and night on earth is confirmed by the verse below.

It is not allowable for the sun to reach the moon, nor does the night overtake the day, but each, in an orbit, is swimming. (Yasin/36: 40)
text.47:
Allah then mentions His second power, which is making the night beneficial for humans, like the benefit of clothing that covers the body. Allah also makes sleep sound for humans so that it is like death, because a person is completely unconscious when sleeping, and their limbs stop working except for the heart and some other organs. Thus, they can rest perfectly, as in Allah's saying:

And it is He who takes your souls by night. (al-An'am/6: 60).

Allah takes the souls at the time of their death, and [the souls] of those not [yet] dead during their sleep. (az-Zumar/39: 42)

Allah makes the day for striving and activity. Just as sleep at night is likened to death, waking up during the day is likened to waking up from death. Likewise, after humans' lives in this world end and they die, they will be resurrected after their death, to be judged by Allah for all that they have done during their lives in the world.
text.48: Allah's third power is that He sends the winds as bearers of good tidings, especially for farmers, that rain, which is His mercy, will soon fall. He also sends down pure rainwater to cleanse bodies and clothes, especially for drinking and other necessities.
text.49:
In this verse, Allah explains that rain is sent down to fertilize lands or soil that are dead and barren. With rainwater, Allah also provides drink to most of His creatures, such as livestock and humans. In another verse, it is explained:

And you see the earth barren, but when We send down rain upon it, it stirs [to life] and swells and puts forth [plants] of every beautiful kind. (al-Hajj/22:5)

And His saying:

So observe the effects of Allah's mercy - how He gives life to the earth after its lifelessness. Indeed, that [same One] will surely give life to the dead, and He is over all things competent. (ar-Rum/30:50)

According to scientists, two things can be discussed from the verse above:

1. Regarding the occurrence of rain

2. Regarding the indication that rainwater brings life, so that it can "... give life thereby to a dead land..."

Regarding the occurrence of rain, the story begins with water flowing along streams that will join other streams to form a much larger river, which eventually flows into the sea. While water flows through streams and rivers, some of it will evaporate due to the heat of the sun (turning into gas), but most of it continues to flow to the sea. It is in the sea that the process of evaporation then takes place.

All the water that evaporates, whether from streams, rivers, or the sea, forms water vapor in the atmosphere. This vapor rises and cools as it reaches higher altitudes in the atmosphere. If there are many gases in the atmosphere, this water vapor will condense into groups of gases called clouds. If the clouds are blown by the wind so that they gather together, and rise upwards to reach even higher parts of the atmosphere, then the water vapor will turn into droplets of ice.

When the clouds become colder due to the lower atmospheric temperature, the water becomes solid (ice) and falls, initially as very small droplets of ice, which usually melt before reaching the ground. Thus, water droplets will fall to earth as rain. (see also ar-Ra'd/13:17; an-Naml/27:60; al-'Ankabut/29:63; Luqman/31:34; as-Sajdah/32:27; Fathir/35:27; az-Zumar/39:21; Qaf/50:9-11).
text.50:
This verse explains that indeed Allah has arranged the descent of rain in turns for mankind. Sometimes it falls during the day or night, sometimes it is directed to water the land of a people who have just performed Salat al-Istisqa (prayer for rain), sometimes it is diverted from a people who commit much disobedience and transgression. All of this is so that people may take lessons from it, and so that they may understand that it is God who regulates the rotation of rain just as He regulates the movement of stars and planets in outer space.

It is not only the descent of rainwater that is regulated in turns, but also its form and condition. Sometimes the water freezes if the air temperature is far below zero and becomes ice. Then, when heated, it turns into liquid, and when heated further, it turns into vapor. Water is an element found in all living things, in plants, animals, and humans, as in the word of Allah:

And We made from water every living thing. (al-Anbiya'/21: 30)

All of this should be food for thought for mankind so that they can be grateful for Allah's blessings. However, most people are reluctant and even deny these blessings.
text.51:
This verse explains that if Allah had willed, He would have sent a messenger to every land, who would give warning. However, Allah sent Muhammad as the final prophet to all of mankind, as Allah says:

Say, "O mankind, indeed I am the Messenger of Allah to you all..." (al-A'raf/7: 158)

And We have not sent you, [O Muhammad], except to all of mankind as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. (Saba'/34: 28)

If other prophets were sent to specific communities, then Allah sent Prophet Muhammad as a messenger to all of mankind as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. Therefore, the miracle given to Prophet Muhammad is no longer temporal, only suitable for a specific people and place. Instead, he was given the Qur'an, which is universal, its values suitable to be applied anywhere and at any time.
text.52:
The Prophet Muhammad was commanded by Allah to convey His message earnestly, to carry out jihad and struggle with full wisdom, patience, perseverance, and without fear or trepidation towards the enemy. The Prophet (saw) must be certain that Allah will surely help, so that victory is in his hands and the hands of the believers. In this verse, Allah forbids the Prophet Muhammad from following the disbelievers who invite him to compromise with them in matters of religion. He must remain firm and consistent in carrying out da'wah and striving to spread the Al-Qur'an.

Linguistically, jihad means striving earnestly, if necessary by sacrificing anything, wealth or life. Jihad can be carried out in times of war or peace. In times of war, jihad is carried out with qital, which is fighting in the way of Allah. Meanwhile, jihad in times of peace can be carried out in the fields of economics, education, culture, and others.

Verse 52 belongs to the group of Makkiyyah verses, revealed before the hijrah in a state of peace. So jihad here is more emphasized on the earnestness of carrying out da'wah, education, and social efforts to improve the condition of society. Allah promises those who strive earnestly that they will always be guided to the straight path. Allah says:

And those who strive for Us - We will surely guide them to Our ways. And indeed, Allah is with the doers of good. (al-'Ankabut/29: 69)
text.53:
This verse contains the fourth sign of Allah's power, which is that He allows two kinds of water to flow side by side, one fresh and sweet, while the other is salty and bitter, as happens at the mouths of large rivers. However, even though they are close together, the taste of the water does not mix, as if there is a wall separating them, so that one does not spoil the taste of the other. Although to the eye the two seas appear to be mixed, in reality the fresh water is separated from the salty water by the power of Allah, as in His saying:

He released the two seas, meeting [side by side]; Between them is a barrier [so] neither of them transgresses. (ar-Rahman/55: 19-20).

According to scientists, Allah has created a separator between sea and river water, even though river water flows rapidly from high places. This *barzakh* (separator) functions to prevent the two waters from erasing each other's characteristics. The salty and fresh water are as if there is a dividing wall between them, so they do not mix. Humans can determine their choice because both salt and fresh water are useful.

In 1873, British marine scientists (with the ship Challenger) discovered differences in the characteristics of the sea in terms of salt content, temperature, types of fish/animals, and so on. Each type of water groups itself in a certain form, separate from other types of water no matter how far it flows. The water of the Amazon River, which flows rapidly into the Atlantic Ocean up to a limit of 200 miles, remains fresh. Springs in the Persian Gulf have unique fish, each of which only lives in its location.

The two seas referred to are the oceans that fill about ¾ of the earth, and the rivers that are accommodated by the land and that radiate springs and large rivers that then flow into the oceans. *Barzakh* (separator) is the water reservoir that exists on earth and the earth's channels that prevent sea water from mixing with river water so that it does not turn it salty.

The state of salt water that penetrates or flows from the ocean to the rocks near the coast, but it does not mix with fresh water that penetrates or flows to the sea from the land. The position of the river flow, which is higher than sea level, allows relatively little fresh water to penetrate the salty sea water but does not mix completely. Another related verse is:

He released the two seas, meeting [side by side]; Between them is a barrier [so] neither of them transgresses. (ar-Rahman/55: 19-20).
text.54:
The fifth sign of Allah's power is that He created humans from sperm. He then made humans have offspring and *musaharah* (affinity through marriage) or familial relationships as a result of the marriage of one's children to others, thus giving rise to family terms such as son-in-law, brother-in-law, mother-in-law, and so on. Allah says:

Was he not a sperm-drop poured out? Then he was a clinging clot, and [Allah] created [him] and proportioned [him], and made of him two mates, the male and the female. (al-Qiyamah/75: 37-39)

Allah created humans with a very beautiful bodily structure, equipped with the five senses, perfected with reason and the ability to think. Humans are also given all facilities so that everything on the surface of the earth is intended for them. Allah says:

Do you not see that Allah has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth and has completed His favors upon you, [both] outwardly and inwardly? (Luqman/31: 20)

From a scientific perspective, some verses related to the verses above are:

Have those who disbelieved not considered that the heavens and the earth were a joined entity, then We separated them, and made from water every living thing? Then will they not believe? (al-Anbiya'/21: 30).

And Allah has created every [living] creature from water. And of them are those that walk on their bellies, and of them are those that walk on two legs, and of them are those that walk on four. Allah creates what He wills. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent. (an-Nur/24: 45).

The three verses above indicate a close relationship between water and the existence of life.

1.  Water is suspected to be very close to living things. Humans and most animals come from seminal fluid.

2.  All life begins with water. Water here is more appropriately interpreted as the sea. This chemical chain is believed to have started from the depths of the ocean. The assumption that life began in the sea is because the atmospheric conditions at that time had not yet developed into an area that could be inhabited by living things.

From this description, the role of water for life is very clear, from the beginning of living things on earth (originating from the depths of the sea), for their survival (water is needed for the formation of organs and to carry out organ functions), and to start life (especially for the "water" animal group that comes from sperm).
text.55:
This verse explains that the polytheists worship gods other than Allah, namely statues and idols that do not benefit them. They worship them merely to follow their desires and continue the traditions of their ancestors, abandoning worship of Allah who created them and has bestowed various blessings. In addition, they have committed evil by helping Satan in his actions of opposing Allah, His Messenger, and the believers, as described in His word:

"And their brothers (the disbelievers and the wicked) help them in error." (al-A'raf/7: 202)

The word *dhahir* in another verse is interpreted as helper. Some *mufassirun* (Quranic commentators) interpret it as humiliated or wasted, so the meaning of the verse becomes: And the disbelievers are very humiliated and wasted in the sight of their Lord.
text.56: Why do the polytheists help Satan in his disobedience to Allah, when He has sent His Messenger to bring good tidings to those who believe and do righteous deeds, and to give warnings to them? They also know that the Messenger was sent to bring good news and give warnings. How foolish are those who oppose the Messenger.
text.57: Allah commanded the Prophet to explain to his people that even though he was sent for their salvation, he did not take any profit for himself whatsoever. He did not ask for any wage from them in conveying this message, except for those who, of their own volition, wanted to do good deeds to draw closer to Allah, by giving charity or voluntary assistance; that is what is good for them.
text.58: This verse commands people to put their trust (tawakal) in Allah, the Ever-Living, the Eternal, who does not die, the Lord of all the worlds, to surrender themselves to Him, and to be patient in all the misfortunes that befall them. God is the One who provides sufficiency for mankind, who leads them to the goal of happiness. Mankind is also commanded to glorify Allah by praising Him, sanctifying Him from all partners, children, wives, and all inappropriate attributes, as the polytheists attribute to Him. Allah's command to put trust (tawakal) in Him does not mean that people no longer need to strive, or no longer need to think about the causes that give rise to that effort, but rather the intention is that people surrender to Allah everything they have striven for. In this verse, Allah commands that trust (tawakal) be placed only in Him, the Ever-Living, because all creatures will die, so it is not appropriate to put trust (tawakal) in anyone other than Allah. Only Allah is the Ever-Living, the Eternal, who knows all the deeds and sins of His servants and who is able to reward their deeds. Good deeds are rewarded with blessings, and bad deeds are rewarded with punishment.
text.59:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah created the heavens, the earth, and what is between them in six periods. The word *yaum* is usually translated as "day," but the "day" in this verse is not a day lasting 24 hours, but *yaum* is interpreted as "period." Then Allah established Himself upon the 'Arasy (see Surah al-A'raf/7: 54).

Every believer believes that Allah is One, eternally living, who created the heavens, the earth, and everything in between in six periods. Allah is the Most Gracious because His mercy and bounty are immense towards mankind, both believers and non-believers.

For those who believe, they should know the attributes of Allah, because this will increase the steadfastness of faith. For those who do not yet know His attributes, they should ask those who truly know about religious matters. Allah says:

So ask the people of knowledge if you do not know. (an-Nahl/16: 43; See also Surah al-Anbiya'/21: 7)

During the time of the Messenger of Allah, if there were issues related to religion, the companions could ask him directly. After the Messenger passed away, Muslims should ask the scholars who are deeply versed in religious matters.
text.60:
After explaining how great the favors and blessings He has bestowed upon them, Allah also explains the attitude of the disbelievers who should be grateful and thankful, but they do the opposite. When those who worship other than Allah are commanded to prostrate to the Most Merciful, they answer, "Who is the Most Merciful?" Their question is like the question of the Children of Israel to Moses when he said, "Indeed, I am a messenger from Rabbul 'alamin." The Children of Israel asked, "Who is Rabbul 'alamin?" In their rebuttal, the polytheists said, "Shall we prostrate to the one you call the Most Merciful, but whom we do not know at all?" The command to prostrate only increases their denial and distance from faith.

It is narrated by adh-Dahhak that the Prophet Muhammad and his companions prostrated after finishing reading this verse, because it is among the verses for which it is recommended to prostrate for the readers and listeners. This prostration is called *sujud tilawah*. There are 15 verses for which *sujud tilawah* is recommended, two of which are in Surah al-Hajj and the other 13 are scattered in Surahs al-A'raf, ar-Ra'd, an-Nahl, al-Isra', Maryam, al-Furqan, an-Naml, as-Sajdah, Sad, Fussilat, an-Najm, al-Inshiqaq, and al-'Alaq. The one in Surah Sad is not only *sujud tilawah*, but also *sujud syukur*. After Allah explains the attitude of the disbelievers who distance themselves from prostrating to Him, He then explains the attitude of people who refuse to prostrate, even becoming more stubborn and distancing themselves from their Lord.
text.61:
Glorified be Allah, Who has placed in the sky constellations whose number is countless. And Allah has also made the sun a radiant light and the moon a shining light.

According to scientists, in discussing celestial objects, the Qur'an also distinguishes between stars and planets. A star is a celestial body that emits light. While a planet only reflects the light it receives from a star. Thus, a star has a source of light, while a planet does not (See Yunus/10: 5 and al-Hijr/15: 16).
text.62:
And Allah is the One who alternates the night and the day, so that it may be a lesson for those who always remember His blessings and contemplate His wondrous creation. Thus, an urge arises to be grateful for Allah's blessings. If the night and day did not alternate, and the sun continued to shine, it would inevitably cause a feeling of boredom and fatigue because of the inability to rest at night. Likewise, if the night continued without being interspersed with sunlight, it would bring destruction to creatures that need it. The alternation of day and night provides an opportunity to perfect shortcomings in voluntary worship, namely, if a person, due to the busyness of working during the day, does not have time to pray or recite wirid, then it can be done at night, as mentioned in a sahih hadith:

Indeed, Allah extends His hand at night so that those who commit sins during the day may repent, and He extends His hand during the day so that those who commit sins at night may repent, until the sun rises from where it sets. (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Musa).

It is narrated that Umar bin Khaththab once prayed Duha for a very long time. When he was reprimanded by one of his companions, he replied that he had missed some wirid that day due to busyness, so he intended to make up for the deficiency with Duha prayer, and then he recited verse 62 of this surah.

Night, day, sun, and moon are four of Allah's blessings. Allah created the night so that humans can rest due to the darkness of the night. The day was created by Allah with the rising of the sun for work. Allah created the sun and moon, each having its own axis and orbit. Tirelessly, and never still, they all continue to circulate.

The alternation of day and night can simply be a change from light to dark. However, psychologically, the transition from light to dark has a completely different impact on mood than the atmosphere of the day. Various experiments have been conducted to observe how the psyche affects night workers. Psychosomatic symptoms (physical symptoms caused by psychological causes) have been observed, ranging from just nausea to more severe symptoms such as mental depression. This is only the short-term effect on the physical and mental well-being of humans. Long-term effects can be more severe. Therefore, Allah has prescribed the night for rest and the day for work. So working at night, which is called overtime, is contrary to human nature as prescribed by Allah.

This condition is not surprising because during the day the earth is exposed to visible light, shifting to yellow as the sun sets, shifting to infrared during Isha prayer, to ultraviolet when the night is late, and approaching dangerous gamma waves near dawn. This exposure causes humans to suffer from psychosomatic disorders if they do not rest and are forced to work.
text.63:
The characteristics of the servants of Allah, the Most Compassionate, are explained starting from verse 63 and the following verses. These characteristics can all be summarized into 9 traits that, if possessed by a Muslim, will earn them Allah's pleasure in this world and the hereafter, and will be placed in a high and noble position, namely in the Garden of Na'im. These traits are:

First: When they walk, their attitude and nature show simplicity, they are far from arrogance, their steps are steady, orderly, and not artificial with the intention of attracting people's attention or to show who they are. That is the nature and attitude of a believer when he walks. Allah says:

"And do not walk upon the earth exultantly." (al-Isra'/17: 37)

Second: If someone utters inappropriate or indecent words to them, they do not respond with similar words. Instead, they respond with good words, containing advice and hope that they will be guided by Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Compassionate, and the Most Merciful. Similarly, with the attitude of the Messenger of Allah when he was attacked and insulted with harsh words, he remained open-hearted and continued to treat those who were immoral with kindness.

Al-hasan al-Basri explained that believers always have open hearts and never utter harsh words. If impolite words are spoken to them, they do not become emotional and do not respond with impolite words either. Some people may think that such a nature and attitude shows weakness and a lack of self-respect, because it is natural for someone who acts impolitely to be repaid with impolite actions as well. However, if pondered deeply, it will certainly lead to prolonged quarrels and disputes. Every believer must prevent prolonged disputes and hostilities. One of the most appropriate and powerful ways to eradicate them is to repay bad actions with good actions so that those who commit bad actions will feel ashamed and realize that they have done something unnatural. This attitude is explained by Allah in His words:

"And not equal are the good deed and the bad. Repel (evil) by that [deed] which is better; and thereupon the one whom between you and him is enmity [will become] as though he was a devoted friend. But none is granted it except those who are patient, and none is granted it except one having a great portion [of good]." (Fussilat/41: 34-35).

Such is the nature and attitude of the believers when they are in the daytime, where they always remember their fellow servants of Allah.
text.64:
Third: Then Allah also explains their attitude and characteristics when relating to the Lord Creator of the universe at night. When the night is quiet and lonely, and people are lulled into a deep sleep, they perform the Tahajud prayer and stand facing the One God. They leave behind the pleasure and comfort of sleep, and they absorb with all their soul and body how pleasant and peaceful it is to confide in God. They perform the night prayer, the Tahajud prayer, as the Messenger of Allah did, because with prayer at night their souls become pure and clean. Their faith increases, their conviction becomes firm that there is no God but Him, His mercy and love are vast, encompassing all His creatures. There they plead and pray with full humility and submission to be forgiven for their sins and mistakes and to be bestowed with His mercy and pleasure. After performing the night prayer, they finally sleep with a feeling of happiness, full of reliance and piety.

Ibn 'Abbas said, "Whoever performs two rak'ahs or more after the Isha prayer, it means he has prayed throughout the night."

In another verse, Allah also explains the characteristics of the believers who perform the night prayer:

Their sides forsake their beds, invoking their Lord in fear and hope, and they spend [in charity] out of what We have provided for them. (as-Sajdah/32: 16).

And His word:

(Is one who is a disbeliever better) or one who is devoutly obedient during periods of the night, prostrating and standing [in prayer], fearing the Hereafter and hoping for the mercy of his Lord? (az-Zumar/39: 9).

And His word:

"They used to sleep but little of the night, And in the hours before dawn they would ask forgiveness." (adz-dzariyat/51: 17-18)
text.65:
Fourth: They are always mindful of the Hereafter and the Day of Reckoning. They are certain that all human deeds will be accounted for on that day, the good will be rewarded manifold, and the evil will be recompensed with a fitting punishment. When they commune with their Lord at night, the awesomeness of that time is pictured in their minds as if they truly see how ferocious the fire of Hell awaits the disobedient servants of Allah to become its prey and sustenance. At that time, their tears flow, and they earnestly plead with their Lord to be freed from the painful torment of Hellfire.

Those who have such strong faith in the Hereafter will certainly use the opportunity of life in this world to do as many good deeds as possible and will not commit evil deeds because they are certain that their actions will be repaid with painful torment. No matter how good a regulation made by humans is and how strict the supervision in its implementation, a person who is not aware of Allah's supervision can escape the bonds of those regulations and laws. However, a person who believes, even if there are no regulations and laws, will not commit a single crime, because he is aware that even if he can escape punishment in this world, he will not be able to escape the torment in the Hereafter. This awareness and realization is firmly embedded in the heart of every Muslim who is given the title "servant of Allah, the Most Merciful."

Hell is the worst place prepared for the disbelieving and disobedient servants of Allah. The disbelievers will abide therein forever, suffering various kinds of torment. Even though their skin has been burned and the heat of the fire of Hell has penetrated into their flesh and bones, they will remain alive to feel the torment, as mentioned in His word:

Indeed, those who disbelieve in Our verses - We will drive them into a Fire. Every time their skins are roasted through We will replace them with other skins so they may taste the punishment. Indeed, Allah is ever Exalted in Might and Wise. (an-Nisa'/4: 56).
