text.67:
Fifth: Another good characteristic of the believers is that in spending their wealth, they are neither extravagant nor miserly, but maintain a balance between these two bad traits. Extravagance will certainly lead to the destruction of property and the corruption of society. A person who is extravagant, even though his personal and family needs have been met with a luxurious lifestyle, will still squander his wealth on other pleasures, such as gambling, womanizing, drinking alcohol, and so on. Thus, he corrupts himself and the society around him. In fact, the wealth entrusted to him by Allah must be maintained as well as possible so that it can benefit himself, his family, and society.

The traits of stinginess and miserliness will also lead to loss and corruption. A miserly person always tries to accumulate wealth even though he himself lives as a poor man, and he does not want to spend his money for the benefit of society. If he is reluctant to spend money even for his own and his family's interests, let alone for the interests of others. Thus, wealth will be accumulated in the hands of one or a few greedy and avaricious people. People with this kind of nature are threatened by Allah with hellfire, as mentioned in His word:

Woe to every slanderer and backbiter, Who amasses wealth and counts it, Thinking that his wealth will make him immortal. Nay! He will surely be thrown into the Crusher. (al-Humazah/104: 1-4).

Such is the nature of the believers in spending their wealth. They are not extravagant, so they do not think about tomorrow, nor are they miserly, so they torture themselves by wanting to accumulate wealth. The balance between these two reprehensible traits is what they always maintain and guard. If they are rich, they can help their community according to their wealth, and if they are poor, they can control their desires by living simply.

Yazid bin Abi Habib said, "Such was the nature of the companions of the Prophet Muhammad saw. They did not eat to live luxuriously and enjoy delicious food, they did not dress to show off their beauty. Rather, they ate only to satisfy their hunger and to strengthen their bodies in order to worship and carry out the commands of Allah. They dressed only to cover their *aurat* and protect their bodies from wind and heat."

'Abdul Malik bin Marwan, when marrying off Fathimah (his daughter) to 'Umar bin 'Abdul 'Aziz, asked his prospective son-in-law, "How will you provide for my daughter?" Umar replied, "I choose the best between two bad traits" (meaning the good trait between two bad traits, namely extravagance and miserliness). Then he recited this verse.
text.68:
Sixth: In this verse, Allah explains further the characteristics of the servants of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, which is that they do not worship other than Allah, and do not associate partners with Him in anything. They truly adhere to pure *tauhid*. When they worship, their worship is solely for Allah, and when they do good deeds, their deeds are for Allah, not for themselves or to be praised by people. When they supplicate, their supplications are truly raised directly to the presence of Allah, not through intermediaries. They are fully convinced that only Allah is capable of answering their prayers.

They do not commit murder against anyone because they realize that a person's life is a right belonging to them. It is not permissible to kill them except with a right that has been established by Allah, such as apostasy or killing someone without right. They will not commit *zina* (unlawful sexual intercourse) because they realize that committing *zina* is a major sin, a deed that is very cursed and angered by Allah. By maintaining the purity of *tauhid*, which is the foundation of *aqidah* (creed), a person's soul will be cleansed, their mind will be clear, and they cannot be swayed by misleading beliefs. By avoiding unlawful killing, they will be cleansed from acts of injustice, and society will be cleansed from chaos. The rights of every member of society will be well-maintained so that they can truly enjoy security and peace. By guarding themselves from the act of *zina*, they will be cleansed from impurity, and society will be cleansed from turmoil and the chaos of lineage that causes various difficulties and instability.

In connection with this, in a hadith of the Prophet saw, it is explained:

'Abdullah bin Mas'ud said, "I asked the Messenger of Allah, 'What is the greatest sin?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'That you set up a rival to Allah when He created you.' I asked again, 'What sin is next?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'The sin of killing your child for fear (of poverty) because he will eat with you.' Then I asked again, 'What sin is next?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'The sin of committing *zina* with your neighbor's wife.' Allah revealed this verse to confirm the words of the Prophet Muhammad." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Then Allah threatens those who commit these sinful acts with a very severe threat, which is Hell on the Day of Judgment as a reward for all the sins they have committed in the world. Allah will even multiply the punishment for them because of the major sins they have committed. They will be thrown into Hell and will remain there. In addition to suffering physical torment such as very hot drinks that burn their throats and intestines, they also suffer mental or spiritual torment, because they are always humiliated and always regret their mistakes when they were in the world.
text.69:
Sixth: In this verse, Allah explains further the characteristics of the servants of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, which is that they do not worship other than Allah, and do not associate partners with Him in anything. They truly adhere to pure *tauhid*. When they worship, their worship is solely for Allah, and when they do good deeds, their deeds are for Allah, not for themselves or to be praised by others. When they supplicate, their supplications are truly raised directly to the presence of Allah, not through intermediaries. They are fully convinced that only Allah is capable of granting their supplications.

They do not commit murder against anyone because they realize that a person's life is a right belonging to them. It is not permissible to kill them except with a right that has been established by Allah, such as apostasy or killing someone without right. They will not commit adultery because they realize that adultery is a major sin, a deed that is very cursed and angered by Allah. By maintaining the purity of *tauhid*, which is the foundation of *aqidah* (creed), a person's soul will be cleansed, their mind will be clear, and they cannot be swayed by misleading beliefs. By avoiding unlawful killing, they will be cleansed from acts of injustice, and society will be cleansed from chaos. The rights of every member of society will be well-preserved so that they can truly enjoy security and tranquility. By guarding themselves from adultery, they will be cleansed from impurity, and society will be cleansed from turmoil and lineage chaos that causes various difficulties and instability.

In connection with this, in a hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) it is explained:

'Abdullah bin Mas'ud said, "I asked the Messenger of Allah, 'What is the greatest sin?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'That you set up a rival to Allah when He created you.' I asked again, 'What sin is next?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'That you kill your child for fear (of poverty) because he will eat with you.' Then I asked again, 'What sin is next?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'That you commit adultery with your neighbor's wife.' Allah revealed this verse to confirm the words of the Prophet Muhammad." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Then Allah threatens those who commit those sins with a very severe threat, namely Hell on the Day of Judgment as a reward for all the sins they have committed in the world. In fact, Allah will multiply the punishment for them because of the major sins they committed. They will be thrown into Hell and will remain there. In addition to suffering physical torment such as very hot drinks that burn their throats and intestines, they also receive inner or spiritual torment, because they are always humiliated and always regret their mistakes when they were in the world.
text.70:
In these verses, Allah explains that those who commit sinful deeds as mentioned in the previous verses, then repent with sincere repentance, return to faith, and consistently perform righteous deeds, their evil deeds will be replaced with good deeds and multiplied rewards because Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Kind, and Most Merciful. According to some commentators (mufasir), the replacement of evil deeds with good rewards is by erasing all the sins that have been committed in the past due to sincere repentance, and then the good deeds they perform after repentance are multiplied in reward so that they can erase the sins that were committed before.

Other commentators (mufasir) say that Allah gives the repentant person a reward equal in number to the sins that have been committed. Then he repents and performs good deeds, then those good deeds will be given multiplied rewards as well. So the repentant person receives two good things: his previous sins are erased, and then he is given a reward equal in number to the sins he has committed.

In a hadith, it is narrated that:

From Abu Thawil Syathab al-Mamdud, he came to the Prophet (saw) and asked, "What is your opinion about a person who commits all sins, there is no sinful act that he does not commit. Is his repentance accepted?" The Prophet (saw) replied, "Have you embraced Islam?" He replied, "I myself testify that there is no god but Allah, the One and Only, and there is no partner for Him. And you are the Messenger of Allah." The Prophet (saw) said, "Yes, that's right. You do good and leave evil. Then Allah will make all of it good for you." He asked again, "Are all my mistakes forgiven?" "Yes," replied the Prophet (saw). "Allahu Akbar," said the man, and he continued to say takbir until he left and disappeared. (Narrated by al-Thabrani)

Then Allah states that the accepted repentance must be accompanied by good deeds. Repentance begins with regret over the evil deeds that have been carried out, and stopping from committing disobedience, accompanied by good deeds to be proof that the repentance is a true repentance and is done sincerely (nasuha).

text.72:
Seventh: In this verse, Allah explains that among the characteristics of the servants of Allah, the Most Gracious, is that they do not want to and never commit false oaths. When they pass by people who like to utter nonsensical and useless words, they pass by without joining them. They realize that a believer is not worthy of serving those who waste their precious time with nonsense, especially if that time is used to discuss things that lead to sinful acts, such as gossiping about people or accusing innocent people, and so on.

Taking false oaths is strictly forbidden in Islam, because when taking an oath, a person has lied and not stated the truth. Many people commit false oaths to defend those who are wrong so that they can seize or possess the rights of others and commit injustice. Whereas, if they did not participate in the oath, the truth would surely be clear and obvious, and there would be no injustice or seizure of rights. As a believer, he must stand on the side of truth and must feel responsible for upholding justice and eradicating injustice.

Umar bin Khaththab was very angry with people who committed false oaths, and he once flogged a person who took a false oath 40 times, smeared his face with black, shaved all the hair on his head, and then paraded him in the middle of the market.

These praiseworthy characteristics and attitudes of the servants of Allah are described by Allah in His word:

"And when they hear ill speech, they turn away from it and say, "For us are our deeds, and for you are your deeds. Peace will be upon you; we do not seek the company of the ignorant." (al-Qasas/28: 55).
text.73:
Eighth: In this verse, Allah explains the characteristics of His servants, which is that they are able to respond to the warnings that Allah gives when they hear them. Their hearts are always open to receiving advice and lessons, and their minds are always contemplating the verses of Allah to be understood and practiced, so that their faith and conviction increase that the teachings that Allah has given them are truly teachings of high value and quality, true teachings that cannot be refuted. It is not surprising that they are very fanatical about these teachings, because they are very convinced of their goodness.

There is a vast difference between them and the polytheists who are also fanatical about their objects of worship. Their fanaticism is blind fanaticism because they do not want to accept the truth even though it is clear and obvious that the creed they adhere to is wrong and contrary to sound reason. No matter how strong and clear the reasons presented to them about the incorrectness of the understanding they adhere to, they will not accept it because their hearts have been closed and their eyes have been blinded to thinking about what is right and what is wrong.
text.74:
Ninth: Among the characteristics of the servants of Allah is that they always supplicate and beseech Him to be granted righteous and good offspring. Their wives and children are truly pleasing to the heart and refreshing to the feelings because their families consist of people who are righteous and pious to God. Thus, the servants of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, will increase on this earth.

In addition to that, they supplicate to Allah that their descendants become people who are all pious, become callers of people to piety, and become leaders for those who are pious. This is the light of faith that has filled their hearts and illuminated them with guidance and direction, so they greatly desire that the number of pious people who receive guidance will continue to increase. Their desire for their children and descendants to become leaders for the pious is not because they desire high positions or absolute power, but solely because of a sincere desire that the inhabitants of this world be filled with people who believe and are pious. It is also aimed at having their children and grandchildren continue their struggle to uphold justice and truth. Thus, even though they themselves have died, they will continue to receive the reward for the struggles of their children and grandchildren, in accordance with the saying of the Messenger of Allah:

"When a person dies, all his deeds are cut off except for three: charity that can be utilized by people, knowledge that he leaves behind that can be benefited from by others after his death, and a righteous child who always prays for him." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah).

Thus, these are nine good qualities possessed by the servants of Allah, the Most Gracious. If a person possesses these qualities, then they are entitled to be called by that title. Those who receive this title will surely be loved by Allah, and in the Hereafter they will receive a very noble and great bounty and mercy.
text.75:
In these two verses, Allah explains the rewards and blessings that will be given to "the servants of the Most Merciful," those servants of Allah who possess perfect qualities and noble character thanks to their patience and perseverance in obeying all of Allah's commands, thanks to their patience and perseverance in fighting their desires to avoid all His prohibitions. They are placed in the most noble and highest place in Paradise. They are greeted by the angels with greetings as a sign of respect for them. This is reflected in Allah's words:

"And the angels enter upon them from every gate, [saying], 'Peace be upon you for what you patiently endured. And excellent is the final home.'" (ar-Ra'd/13: 23-24).

Then Allah explains that the blessings and favors they receive are eternal and never-ending blessings and favors. There is no doubt that that place is the best place to settle and the best place to reside.

text.77: In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to say to the disbelievers that because of their disbelief, arrogance, and pride, Allah will not care about them in the slightest. They will never receive the blessings given to those who believe; instead, they will receive a fitting recompense, which is the Hellfire (Jahanam). They will be thrown into it and receive a punishment whose severity cannot be described, and they will abide eternally in that Hell.
